Hey Sreeharsh, please meet Yannick your incredible E-Mentor we've been telling you about :smile:.  Feel free to introduce yourselves, say a little bit about what you would like to get out of the mentorship and continue chatting within this channel. :wave:

I will now be leaving the channel, but please direct message myself or penny-prospela if you have any questions. All the best for now! :slightly_smiling_face:
_@emma has left the channel_
_@emma has left the channel_

Hello Yannick,

it's really nice to meet you. I'm Harsh and I'm recent VFX graduate from London South Bank University. 

I'm interested in a career doing modelling and texturing. I also like lookdev as well.

I've recently got a job at framestore as a render wrangler. It's going great, and I can use my free time in there to develop my skills and work on my personal projects. 

That's just a brief intro about me. It would be really nice to have you here to support me through my learning and giving me feedbacks on my works.
Hi Harsh, nice to meet you. Good to see you are already working in the industry. Let me know how I can help you.
Do you have a reel to look at? Let me know your questions.
I am currently working at Dneg as a senior generalist for the build department. I create assets for films, like characters, vehicles and environments.
You can see some of my work here: <http://cgifocus.com/portfolio|cgifocus.com/portfolio> and my reel <http://cgifocus.com/demoreel|cgifocus.com/demoreel>

That's an amazing reel.

So in my free time at framestore I'm looking to develop my skills in modelling primarily. 

One thing I struggle to figure out on my own is what area should I really specialise in. Or be a generalist. 
I'm getting these mixed opinion from everyone. Some of them like generalist is a good thing and others are like you really have to pick an area where you want to focus.

I simply enjoy doing modelling and texturing in my University time than anything else in the vfx pipeline. 

Here is my reel I include 

<https://vimeo.com/390596258|https://vimeo.com/390596258>
<http://sreeharshbaburajan.co.uk|sreeharshbaburajan.co.uk>

attachments.title: Show_Reel_2020
attachments.video_html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/390596258?autoplay=1&app_id=122963" width="400" height="225" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen" allowfullscreen title="Show_Reel_2020"></iframe>

text: Your reel is good. You should re order it and have the robot first especially the back view, then the car followed by the little droid, then the Buddha. I would remove the space ship corridor as the lighting needs more work and the digi double. The cottage should be put forward as it is a nice little piece. Remember recruiters usually watch the first minute of the reel, so put the most impressive work first. It is hard as you usually want to put your favorite piece first but it isn't always the most relevant pieces. I also have the same issue, in some previous reel I would put the shots that I really enjoy working on but weren't the most technical.

Thank you Yannick for taking a look at my reel. I would follow the order you advised. You're right, sometimes it's hard to push the favourite works to the back. 

But yes I will defenetly do as you said.

As for the modeler or generalist path, it is a hard one, but i would say not to be just a modeler, if you can do texturing as well this will be a big plus. Being specialized means that you can only work for the big companies. You contract might be shorter as you will do the task required and then move on. As a generalist you tend to stay longer as you would cover more of the project. I work with facial modelers, or groomers, there are so specialized they come and go. At Dneg, they like people that can do more things, and that can mean just doing modelling and texturing.
Even though modelling is what I enjoy most, I also practice my texturing and lookdev along with it.

That's good. look dev is good to know although it can be a bit more tricky due to the pipeline. On Bond, I got to to the modeling/texturing/look dev, which was nice as I was doing the all asset my self. Only the grooming was done by someone else I didn't have the time.

Here at framestore they told me that I can switch if they have a modelling position opens, I can apply for it.

But for that I need to build a strong reel.

I'm starting a personal project this week, if that's okay I will share the wip with you and if you can give  a feedback on it. It would be great
yes please do. Which soft are you using?
I still love to use maya and zbrush for modelling,
Learning houdini alongside, which is good for procedural modelling. Also this is good for procedural terrain landscapes generation
That's good, they are widely used. Also for your reel it is also good to show topology, so adding some wireframe is good to show your expertise.
Yes, that's one thing I forgot to add, I will render some wire frames and update the reel
Nice one. let me know you have more question or if you need me to review anything else. Speak to you later
Absolutely,  thank you for your time Yannick. I'll get back to you.
